verses.text: Wine is a mocker, strong drink is a brawler, and whoever is led astray by them is not wise.
verses.comment: This verse warns against the dangers of drunkenness, emphasizing the need for self-control and discipline—qualities valued in both personal and communal life.

verses.text: The terror of a king is like the roaring of a lion; whoever provokes him forfeits his own life.
verses.comment: Earthly authority is given weight, hinting at the importance of rightful leadership—echoing the Scriptural idea of order established by God (Romans 13:1).

verses.text: It is honorable for a man to avoid strife, but every fool is quick to quarrel.
verses.comment: Pursuit of peace is seen as wisdom, anticipating the New Testament call to be peacemakers and live in charity toward all (Matthew 5:9).

verses.text: The sluggard does not plow in autumn; at harvest he looks but finds nothing.
verses.comment: Diligence leads to fruitfulness—a principle applied spiritually to those who faithfully labor in God’s field (Matthew 9:37-38).

verses.text: Counsel in a man’s heart is deep water, but a man of understanding will draw it out.
verses.comment: Spiritual insight is often hidden and must be sought with prayer and discernment—a lifelong process for the wise.

verses.text: Many a man claims steadfast love, but a faithful man who can find?
verses.comment: True faithfulness is rare, a virtue best embodied in Christ, and modeled by those who seek to imitate Him in daily life.

verses.text: The righteous who walks in integrity—blessed are his children after him!
verses.comment: A life of virtue leaves a legacy of blessing, honoring the familial and communal dimensions of living out the faith.

verses.text: A king who sits on the throne of judgment winnows all evil with his eyes.
verses.comment: The king’s role as judge prefigures Christ the King, who will judge the living and the dead (John 5:22; Matthew 25:31-46).

verses.text: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am clean from my sin”?
verses.comment: All have sinned and need forgiveness; only through grace and sacramental confession is the heart made pure again.

verses.text: Differing weights and differing measures—the LORD detests them both.
verses.comment: Justice and honesty in dealings reflect God’s own righteousness and the necessity of upright conduct.

verses.text: Even a child makes himself known by his deeds, whether his conduct is pure and upright.
verses.comment: Actions reveal the heart. The stress on deeds anticipates the teaching that faith must be lived out through good works (James 2:17).

verses.text: The hearing ear and the seeing eye—the LORD has made them both.
verses.comment: God is the creator of all and thus sovereign over our senses and understanding—inviting a response of gratitude and humility.

verses.text: Do not love sleep, lest you become poor; stay awake, and you will have plenty of bread.
verses.comment: Industry and vigilance are repeatedly commended as virtues leading to prosperity, both materially and spiritually.

verses.text: "Bad, bad," says the buyer; but when he goes away, then he boasts.
verses.comment: Dishonest dealings are exposed. The passage warns against manipulative practices and highlights integrity in speech.

verses.text: There is gold and abundance of jewels, but lips that possess knowledge are a rare treasure.
verses.comment: Wisdom is valued above material gain, echoing later teachings about storing up treasures in heaven (Matthew 6:19-21).

verses.text: Take a man’s garment when he has put up security for a stranger; hold it in pledge when it is for foreigners.
verses.comment: This practical advice underscores the need for prudence when dealing with financial obligations and pledges.

verses.text: Bread gained by deceit is sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth will be full of gravel.
verses.comment: Short-term gain through sin brings long-term sorrow. Justice is ultimately inescapable.

verses.text: Plans are established by counsel; by wise guidance wage war.
verses.comment: Seeking wise counsel, especially in significant matters, points to the biblical principle of communal discernment.

verses.text: Whoever goes about as a gossip reveals secrets; therefore do not associate with a talker.
verses.comment: Guarding one’s speech is a mark of wisdom, aligning with the scriptural warnings against slander and discord.

verses.text: If one curses his father or his mother, his lamp will go out in utter darkness.
verses.comment: Honoring parents is tied to spiritual well-being, resonating with the commandment and the promise it carries (Ephesians 6:2-3).

verses.text: An inheritance gained hastily in the beginning will not be blessed in the end.
verses.comment: Rushed gain or unearned riches often fail to endure. Lasting blessings require patience and virtue.

verses.text: Do not say, “I will repay evil!” Wait for the LORD, and he will deliver you.
verses.comment: This anticipates Jesus’ command to love enemies (Matthew 5:44), showing that vengeance belongs to God alone.

verses.text: Unequal weights are an abomination to the LORD, and false scales are not good.
verses.comment: Honesty in business dealings is a recurring concern, showing God’s concern for justice in all areas of life.

verses.text: A man’s steps are directed by the LORD; how then can man understand his own way?
verses.comment: Divine providence governs human affairs, inviting trust and surrender to God’s mysterious plans.

verses.text: It is a snare to say rashly, “It is holy,” and to reflect only after making vows.
verses.comment: Promises made to God should not be taken lightly. Careful discernment and commitment in vows point to the seriousness of entering sacred promises, such as those in the sacraments.

verses.text: A wise king scatters the wicked and drives the wheel over them.
verses.comment: The imagery of judgment links to ultimate justice rendered by Christ, who purifies His people (Malachi 3:2-3).

verses.text: The spirit of man is the lamp of the LORD, searching all his innermost parts.
verses.comment: The human soul is illuminated by God, who alone knows the depths of our hearts. Spiritual examination is a lifelong discipline.

verses.text: Steadfast love and faithfulness preserve the king, and by righteousness his throne is upheld.
verses.comment: Mercy and fidelity are qualities that mark true kingship, seen perfectly in the reign of Christ.

verses.text: The glory of young men is their strength, but the splendor of old men is their gray hair.
verses.comment: Both youth and age are gifts—strength to serve, wisdom to guide. The intergenerational life in the Church builds up the whole body (see 1 Corinthians 12:12-27).

verses.text: Blows that wound cleanse away evil; so do stripes to the innermost parts.
verses.comment: Discipline—even when painful—purifies and instructs, reminding us of the Father’s loving correction of His children (Hebrews 12:6).
